citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility’s updated program of veterinary care did not include written provisions and outlined care for the newly
acquired guinea pigs, nor identified the current species on hand. The written program of veterinary care is needed to
ensure that the facility understands the expectations of the attending veterinarian regarding the veterinary care of
regulated animals. The facility should ensure that the written program of veterinary care is available for review during all
USDA inspections.
Each facility shall employ an attending veterinarian under formal arrangements. In the case of a part-time attending
veterinarian or consultant arrangements, the formal arrangements shall include a written program of veterinary care and
regularly scheduled visits to the premises of the breeder.
Correct by May 1, 2023.

The facility has not updated their acquisition and disposition records for the hedgehogs, sugar gliders, or guinea pigs on
hand.
Complete and accurate acquisition and disposition records, including offspring born at the facility, records must be kept to
allow for accurate identification and medical care of the animals, as well as lawful tracking of their movement.
The facility shall make, keep and maintain records that fully and correctly include all the required acquisition and
disposition information. This information must include the name and address of the person from whom the animals were
acquired, the USDA license number of the person if licensed or the vehicle license number and state and driver’s license
number and state if not licensed, the name and address of the person to whom an animal was given/sold, the date of
acquisition or disposition, the species of animal and the number of animals involved.
Correct by May 1, 2023.

The facility has not documented a contingency plan. A plan is important to be in place in preparation for unexpected
disasters or events, as well a detailed strategy to address the needed handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and
care of the animals in the event of an emergency or disaster. The facility shall develop and document an appropriate
contingency plan available for review upon USDA inspections.
Correct by May 10, 2023.

The interior walls of the building housing guinea pigs had areas of exposed insulation material. Indoor building facilities
must be constructed and maintained so that surfaces are substantially impervious to moisture so that they can be readily
cleaned and sanitized.
Correct by May 3, 2023.

Two guinea pig enclosures had a harden, caked layer of soiled bedding and feces underneath the fresh bedding that’s
been placed on top. Although none of the guinea pigs had direct contact with this area, the degree of layered debri and
waste presented odors near these enclosures in the room.
Increased accumulations of debri and waste with ineffective cleaning and sanitation practices foster breeding grounds for
pests and negatively impact the health of the animals housed in the affected and neighboring enclosures.
Primary enclosures must be cleaned often enough to prevent an accumulation of excreta or debris. In addition,
enclosures must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks in the manner provided in paragraph (a)(4) of this section.
Correct by April 20, 2023.

The building housing guinea pigs had excessive amounts of cobwebs and bedding debris along the primary enclosures,
as well as the interior surfaces of the building.
Excess buildup of unused items can attract pests harboring diseases that can be spread to regulated animals, as well as
make it difficult to maintain husbandry standards.
The premise grounds shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to prevent animals from injury and facilitate good
husbandry practices that place accumulations of trash in designated areas and cleared as necessary to protect the health
of the animals.
Correct by April 26, 2023.

The enclosure housing one female hedgehog had piles of feces and debris present throughout the flooring. One corner of
the enclosure contained aged feces that was now white in appearance. While the facility explained they were only spot-
cleaning to prevent stress during pregnancy, the amount of excreta and waste now present was encompassing the
flooring within the bin.
The accumulation of excreta and decaying food can pose health risks to the animals by contaminating the enclosure and
attracting unwanted vermin that may carry diseases. . Excreta shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as
necessary to prevent contamination of the animals contained therein and to minimize disease hazards reduce odors.
Correct by April 20, 2023.

The building housing hedgehogs and sugar gliders had moderate accumulation of cobwebs, bedding debris, and other
miscellaneous items along the sides of the primary enclosures, as well as the floor and walls of the building.
Excess buildup of unused items can attract pests harboring diseases that can be spread to regulated animals, as well as
make it difficult to maintain husbandry standards.
The premise grounds shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to prevent animals from injury and facilitate good
husbandry practices that place accumulations of trash in designated areas and cleared as necessary to protect the health
of the animals.
Correct by April 26, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee and facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(1) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The facility’s updated program of veterinary care did not include written provisions and outlined care for the newly 
acquired guinea pigs, nor identified the current species on hand. The written program of veterinary care is needed to 
ensure that the facility understands the expectations of the attending veterinarian regarding the veterinary care of 
regulated animals. The facility should ensure that the written program of veterinary care is available for review during all

Each facility shall employ an attending veterinarian under formal arrangements. In the case of a part-time attending 
veterinarian or consultant arrangements, the formal arrangements shall include a written program of veterinary care and 
regularly scheduled visits to the premises of the breeder. 
Correct by May 1, 2023. 
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility has not updated their acquisition and disposition records for the hedgehogs, sugar gliders, or guinea pigs on 
hand.  
Complete and accurate acquisition and disposition records, including offspring born at the facility, records must be kept to

allow for accurate identification and medical care of the animals, as well as lawful tracking of their movement.  
The facility shall make, keep and maintain records that fully and correctly include all the required acquisition and

acquired, the USDA license number of the person if licensed or the vehicle license number and state and driver’s license 
number and state if not licensed, the name and address of the person to whom an animal was given/sold, the date of 
acquisition or disposition, the species of animal and the number of animals involved. 
Correct by May 1, 2023. 
2.134 
   
Contingency planning. 
The facility has not documented a contingency plan. A plan is important to be in place in preparation for unexpected 
disasters or events, as well a detailed strategy to address the needed handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and 
care of the animals in the event of an emergency or disaster. The facility shall develop and document an appropriate

Correct by May 10, 2023. 
3.26(d) 
   
Facilities, indoor. 
The interior walls of the building housing guinea pigs had areas of exposed insulation material. Indoor building facilities 
must be constructed and maintained so that surfaces are substantially impervious to moisture so that they can be readily 
cleaned and sanitized. 
Correct by May 3, 2023. 
3.31(a)(1) 
   
Sanitation.

Two guinea pig enclosures had a harden, caked layer of soiled bedding and feces underneath the fresh bedding that’s 
been placed on top. Although none of the guinea pigs had direct contact with this area, the degree of layered debri and 
waste presented odors near these enclosures in the room. 
Increased accumulations of debri and waste with ineffective cleaning and sanitation practices foster breeding grounds for 
pests and negatively impact the health of the animals housed in the affected and neighboring enclosures.   
Primary enclosures must be cleaned often enough to prevent an accumulation of excreta or debris. In addition, 
enclosures must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks in the manner provided in paragraph (a)(4) of this section. 
Correct by April 20, 2023. 
3.31(b) 
   
Sanitation. 
The building housing guinea pigs had excessive amounts of cobwebs and bedding debris along the primary enclosures, 
as well as the interior surfaces of the building. 
Excess buildup of unused items can attract pests harboring diseases that can be spread to regulated animals, as well as 
make it difficult to maintain husbandry standards. 
The premise grounds shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to prevent animals from injury and facilitate good 
husbandry practices that place accumulations of trash in designated areas and cleared as necessary to protect the health 
of the animals. 
Correct by April 26, 2023. 
3.131(a) 
   
Sanitation. 
The enclosure housing one female hedgehog had piles of feces and debris present throughout the flooring. One corner of 
the enclosure contained aged feces that was now white in appearance. While the facility explained they were only spot-

cleaning to prevent stress during pregnancy, the amount of excreta and waste now present was encompassing the 
flooring within the bin. 
The accumulation of excreta and decaying food can pose health risks to the animals by contaminating the enclosure and 
attracting unwanted vermin that may carry diseases. . Excreta shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as 
necessary to prevent contamination of the animals contained therein and to minimize disease hazards reduce odors.  
Correct by April 20, 2023. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
The building housing hedgehogs and sugar gliders had moderate accumulation of cobwebs, bedding debris, and other 
miscellaneous items along the sides of the primary enclosures, as well as the floor and walls of the building. 
Excess buildup of unused items can attract pests harboring diseases that can be spread to regulated animals, as well as 
make it difficult to maintain husbandry standards. 
The premise grounds shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to prevent animals from injury and facilitate good 
husbandry practices that place accumulations of trash in designated areas and cleared as necessary to protect the health

Correct by April 26, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee and facility representative.
